org.ehoffman.testing.testng
Class ExtensibleTestNGListener

java.lang.Object
  org.ehoffman.testing.testng.ExtensibleTestNGListener
All Implemented Interfaces:
org.testng.IInvokedMethodListener, org.testng.IMethodInterceptor, org.testng.ITestListener, org.testng.ITestNGListener
Direct Known Subclasses:
AnnotationEnforcer
public class ExtensibleTestNGListener
extends Object
implements org.testng.IMethodInterceptor, org.testng.IInvokedMethodListener, org.testng.ITestListener

When extend this class, as you must to use the Test-Extensions framework, you should call setInterceptors(Class, List) method in a static block in your implementation class. This will configure the set of Listeners you want applied to your tests, examples include LogBackInterceptor, GroupsInterceptor, BrokenInterceptor and the FixtureInterceptor.

The only intercepter absolutely needed to use fixtures is the FixtureInterceptor

Here is an example implementation
public class MyEnforcer extends ExtensibleTestNGListener {
  private static boolean ideMode = Boolean.valueOf(System.getProperty("java.class.path").contains("org.testng.eclipse"));
  private static boolean integrationPhase = Boolean.valueOf(System.getProperty("integration_phase"));
  private static boolean runBrokenTests = false;
  
  static {
    ideMode = false;
    ExtensibleTestNGListener.setInterceptors(MyEnforcer.class,
    Arrays.asList(new LogBackInterceptor(),
      new BrokenInterceptor(runBrokenTests, Broken.class, ideMode),
      new GroupsInterceptor(new String[] { "unit", "functional" }, new String[] { "remote-integration" }, integrationPhase, ideMode),
      new FixtureInterceptor()));
    }
  
  public static boolean isIntegrationPhase() {
    return integrationPhase;
  }
  
  public static boolean isIdeMode() {
    return ideMode;
  }
  
  public static boolean isRunBrokenTests() {
    return runBrokenTests;
  }
}

Author:
rex hoffman
